raw_text:
The Producers scoops stage awards
 
 The Producers has beaten Mary Poppins in the battle of the blockbuster West End musicals at the Olivier Awards.
 
 The Producers won three prizes at the UK's most prestigious annual theatre awards, while Mary Poppins won two. Mel Brooks' hit show triumphed in the battle for best new musical, where it was up against Mary Poppins and Andrew Lloyd Webber's The Woman in White. Alan Bennett's The History Boys was the big winner in the straight theatre categories, picking up three trophies. But all eyes were on the musical prizes after The Producers, Mary Poppins and The Woman in White all had high-profile openings in the last six months.
 
 The Producers' Nathan Lane, a last-minute replacement for Richard Dreyfuss, beat his former co-star Lee Evans to win best musical actor. Lane has already left the production. A smash hit on Broadway before moving to London, the show also won best musical performance in a supporting role for Conleth Hill, who plays director Roger DeBris. Mary Poppins' awards came for best choreography and best musical actress for its star Laura Michelle Kelly. It led the nominations going into Sunday's ceremony at London's Hilton hotel, up for nine awards. Both shows are stage adaptations of 1960s films. The History Boys, set in a grammar school in the early 1980s and partly based on Bennett's experiences as a teacher, was named best new play.
 
 It also won best actor for Richard Griffiths, who beat his Harry Potter film co-star Michael Gambon, nominated for Endgame, as well as Jonathan Pryce and Ben Whishaw. The play also won National Theatre artistic director Nicholas Hytner best director and Bennett got a special award for outstanding contribution to British theatre. Dame Judi Dench, who starred in All's Well That Ends Well at the Gielgud, lost out in the best supporting role category to Amanda Harris, who played Emilia in Othello for the Royal Shakespeare Company. The Olivier Awards have been handed out by the Society of London since 1976.
 
 - Best lighting design - His Dark Materials designed by Paule Constable at the Olivier 
  - Best sound design - The Woman in White designed by Mick Potter at the Palace 
  - Best new opera - Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk at the Royal Opera House 
  - Outstanding achievement in opera - Thomas Ades and the Royal Opera House for the world premiere of The Tempest 
  - Best costume design - All's Well That Ends Well designed by Deirdre Clancy at the Gielgud 
  - Best Revival - Hamlet by William Shakespeare at The Old Vic 
  - Best set design - His Dark Materials designed by Giles Cadle at the Olivier 
  - Outstanding musical production - Grand Hotel at the Donmar Warehouse 
  - Best supporting role in a musical - Conleth Hill for The Producers at Theatre Royal, Drury Lane 
  - Best theatre choreographer - Matthew Bourne and Stephen Mear for Mary Poppins at the Prince Edward 
  - Best actor - Richard Griffiths for The History Boys at the Lyttelton 
  - Outstanding achievement or performance in an affiliate theatre - Andrew Scott for A Girl in A Car With A Man at the Jerwood Theatre Upstairs at the Royal Court 
  - Best new dance production - Rambert Dance Company's Swamp at Sadler's Wells 
  - Outstanding achievement in dance - San Francisco Ballet for their season at Sadler's Wells 
  - Best performance in a supporting role - Amanda Harris for Othello at Trafalgar Studios 
  - Best actress - Clare Higgins for Hecuba at the Donmar Warehouse 
  - Best musical actor - Nathan Lane for The Producers at Theatre Royal, Drury Lane 
  - Best musical actress - Laura Michelle Kelly for Mary Poppins at the Prince Edward 
  - Best director - Nicholas Hytner for The History Boys at the Lyttelton 
  - Best new play - The History Boys by Alan Bennett at the Lyttelton 
  - Best new musical - The Producers at Theatre Royal, Drury Lane 
  - Special award - Alan Bennett for his outstanding contribution to British theatre
llama3.2:1b: The Producers won three prizes, including best actor and best supporting role in a musical, at the Olivier Awards.
Nathan Lane beat Richard Dreyfuss for best musical actor.
Lee Evans won best supporting role in a musical but was replaced by Nathan Lane.
The Producers also won best director, Nicholas Hytner, and special awards for Alan Bennett's "The History Boys" and Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk at the Royal Opera House.
The show that lost to The Producers is Mary Poppins.
llama3.2:3b: The Producers won three Olivier Awards including best new musical, Nathan Lane won best musical actor, and Conleth Hill won best supporting role in a musical.
Mary Poppins won two awards for best choreography and best musical actress.
The History Boys won three awards, including best new play and best director.
Alan Bennett received a special award for his outstanding contribution to British theatre.
gemma2:2b: The Producers won three Olivier Awards, including best new musical.
The show's Nathan Lane took the award for best musical actor and Laura Michelle Kelly received an award for best musical actress in a supporting role.
Mary Poppins won awards for choreography and best musical actress.
Alan Bennett's The History Boys won best new play,  Richard Griffiths won best actor, Nicholas Hytner was named best director.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The Producers won three Olivier Awards (best musical) at the awards ceremony in London.
Mary Poppins and The Woman in White were nominated but did not win, while the History Boys won best new play and received special recognition from Alan Bennett.
Both shows are adaptations of 1960s films, and both features grandiose productions with elaborate lighting designs.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The Producers won three Olivier Awards over Mary Poppins, securing victories in best new musical, supporting actor (Nathan Lane), and musical actress (Laura Michelle Kelly) categories.
Mary Poppins also took home two awards, including best choreography and musical actress.

The History Boys emerged as the biggest winner with three trophies, while The Producers edged out other high-profile productions such as The Woman in White and Hamlet at the Olivier Awards ceremony held at London's Hilton hotel.
qwen2.5:3b: The Producers won three Olivier Awards beating Mary Poppins and The Woman in White.
It triumphed in best new musical alongside Mary Poppins but fell short against Conleth Hill who won best musical performance in a supporting role.
The History Boys was the big winner in straight theatre categories, picking up three trophies including best new play for Alan Bennett's script.
Dame Judi Dench lost out in best supporting actress to Amanda Harris at the Gielgud.

Other winners included Matthew Bourne and Stephen Mear for Mary Poppins' Best Theatre Choreography, Richard Griffiths for The History Boys in Best Actor, Nicholas Hytner for The History Boys as Best Director, Clare Higgins for Hecuba in Best Performance in a Supporting Role, and Laura Michelle Kelly for Mary Poppins in Best Musical Actress.
opencoder:1.5b: The Producers' scoops stage awards won three prize shows during the last six months.
They won best actor for Richard Griffiths and best director for Nicholas Hytner in Britain's most prestigious annual theatre awards.
The show won best musical performance for its star Laura Michelle Kelly, which is also set at Theatre Royal, Drury Lane.
It also won National Theatre artistic director Nicholas Hytner's best director award for outstanding contribution to British theatre.
Both plays are stage adaptations of 19th-century films and have also won awards in other theatre categories.
smollm:1.7b: The Producers won three prizes at the UK's most prestigious annual theatre awards, while Mary Poppins won two.
Mel Brooks' hit show triumphed in the battle for best new musical, where it was up against Mary Poppins and Andrew Lloyd Webber's The Woman in White.
Alan Bennett's The History Boys also won a special award for outstanding contribution to British theatre.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The Producers and Mary Poppins won several awards at the Olivier Awards.

The Producers won three prizes in straight theatre categories (best musical actor Nathan Lane, best supporting role Conleth Hill) and two in musicals (best musical performance in a supporting role Laura Michelle Kelly), while Mary Poppins also secured two awards.
Alan Bennett's *The History Boys* won three new play awards, and Mel Brooks' *Melody of the Five* received second place for best new musical.
Both plays were adapted from 1960s films.

The Producers also won six musical prizes: best actor Nathan Lane, best supporting actor Michael Gambon, Jonathan Pryce, Ben Whishaw, best actor in a supporting role Conleth Hill; and best director Nicholas Hytner.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Producers has beaten Mary Poplin's stage adaptation of the hit Broadway musical in three categories during the Olivier Awards.
The Producers won Best New Musical, while Mary Poplin's The Woman in White won for Best Choreography and Best Musical Performance in a Supporting Role.
Both shows were adapted from the hit Broadway production of 1960s films.
The History Boys won three prizes at the awards ceremony, with Nathan Lane winning Best Musical Actor for his role as Roger DeBriss in the show.
Laura Michelle Kelly received the Outstanding Performance Award for Mary Poplin's production of The Woman in White, while Michael Gambon was nominated for Best New Play.
Damien Judi Dench lost out to Amanda Harris in the Best Supporting Role category for her portrayal of Emilia in Otello for the Royal Shakespeare Company.

Paule Constable won Best Lighting Design at the Olivier Awards for his work on The Woman in White, and Mick Potter was nominated for Best Sound Design for his performance in The Tempest at the Palace Theatre.
Thomas Ades' world premiere of The Tempest received a Special Award at the ceremony.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The summary of the article provides a brief overview of some of the key points mentioned in the text.
The Producers won three awards at the UK's most prestigious annual theatre awards, while Mary Poppins won two.
This highlights that both shows received high praise from the industry for their performances and production values.
Additionally, it mentions that Mel Brooks' hit show triumphed over Mary Poppins in the battle of the West End musicals.

The summary also includes information about other notable winners at the event, including Conleth Hill for The History Boys, Richard Griffiths for The History Boys, and Jonathan Pryce for Harry Potter and the Cursed Child.

Mel Brooks' The Producers beat Mary Poppins and Andrew Lloyd Webber's The Woman in White in both musicals categories.
The History Boys won three trophies, while The Producers won two for Nathan Lane, who replaced Richard Dreyfuss as star actor.
Amanda Harris received Best Supporting Actress for Othello at Trafalgar Studios.
Dame Judi Dench lost to Amanda Harris.

granite3.1-dense:2b: At the Olivier Awards, the prestigious UK theater honors, The Producers secured three wins over Mary Poppins and Andrew Lloyd Webber's The Woman in White.

Key winners included Nathan Lane for best musical actor in The Producers, Conleth Hill for best supporting role in a musical, Laura Michelle Kelly for best musical actress in Mary Poppins, and Richard Griffiths for best actor in The History Boys.
The History Boys also claimed multiple categories, including best new play, best actor (Richard Griffiths), and Nicholas Hytner's outstanding contribution to British theatre.
